content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="f of t, equals, g of t, for 0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12; f of t, equals, the fraction with numerator t squared, and denominator 8, end fraction, minus, 3 t, plus 83, for, 12 less than t, less than or equal to 24."><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>for</mtext><mspace width="0.45em"></mspace><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>83</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>for</mtext><mspace width="0.45em"></mspace><mn>12</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “g of t, in degrees Fahrenheit.” The data in the table are as follows, Column 1. t is 0. g of t is 87. Column 2. t is 4. g of t is 81.5. Column 3. t is 6. g of t is 76. Column 4. t is 8. g of t is 70.5. Column 5. t is 12. g of t is 65. "><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="12em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(degrees Fahrenheit)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>87</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>81.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>76</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>70.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>65</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The temperature of a room, in degrees Fahrenheit, on a certain day is modeled by the function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined above, where <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a differentiable function and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Values of <math alttext="g of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected values of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above.

(a)      According to the model <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the average rate of change of the temperature of the room over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours?

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="f of t, equals, g of t, for 0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12; f of t, equals, the fraction with numerator t squared, and denominator 8, end fraction, minus, 3 t, plus 83, for, 12 less than t, less than or equal to 24."><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>for</mtext><mspace width="0.45em"></mspace><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>83</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>for</mtext><mspace width="0.45em"></mspace><mn>12</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “g of t, in degrees Fahrenheit.” The data in the table are as follows, Column 1. t is 0. g of t is 87. Column 2. t is 4. g of t is 81.5. Column 3. t is 6. g of t is 76. Column 4. t is 8. g of t is 70.5. Column 5. t is 12. g of t is 65. "><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="12em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(degrees Fahrenheit)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>87</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>81.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>76</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>70.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>65</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The temperature of a room, in degrees Fahrenheit, on a certain day is modeled by the function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined above, where <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a differentiable function and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Values of <math alttext="g of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected values of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above.

(a)      According to the model <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the average rate of change of the temperature of the room over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours?

(b)      Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="f prime of 10"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the instantaneous rate of change in the temperature of the room, in degrees Fahrenheit per hour, at time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(c)      Is <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> continuous for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 24 "><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(d)      Find <math alttext="f prime of 20"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the instantaneous rate of change in the temperature of the room, in degrees Fahrenheit per hour, at time <math alttext="t equals 20"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Confirm whether hypotheses or conditions of a selected definition, theorem, or test have been satisfied.
